Chapter 11, Part 2: The Bodhisattva Lion's Roar
At that time, Bodhisattva-MahÄsattva Lion's Roar said to the Buddha:
World-Honored One!
As you said before, the four kinds of people are like the mango fruit.ğŸ”½There are those whose conduct is subtle but whose minds are not upright and true.
There are those whose minds are subtle but whose conduct is not upright and true.ğŸ”½There are those whose minds are subtle and whose conduct is also upright and true.
There are those whose minds are not subtle and whose conduct is not upright and true.
How can the first two kinds be known?
As the Buddha said, although one relies on these two, one cannot know them.
The Buddha said:
Excellent, excellent!
Good man!
The mango fruit analogy for the two kinds of people is indeed difficult to know.
Because it is difficult to know, I say in the sÅ«tras that one should live with them;
if living with them does not make one know, one should live with them for a long time;
If one stays for a long time and still does not know, one should use wisdom;
If wisdom does not know, one should deeply contemplate;
Because of contemplation, one will know who observes precepts and who violates precepts.
Good man!
Endowed with these four things, staying together for a long time, with wisdom and contemplation, one will then know who observes precepts and who violates precepts.
Good man!
Precepts are of two kinds, and precept observance is also twofold:
One is ultimate precepts, and the other is not ultimate.
There are people who observe precepts due to causes and conditions. The wise should contemplate whether this person observes precepts for the sake of material gain,
Or for the sake of ultimate observance?
Good man!
The precepts of the TathÄgata are without causes and conditions, and therefore they are called ultimate precepts.

For this reason, although the Bodhisattva is harmed by evil beings, he does not give rise to anger or obstruction. Therefore the TathÄgata is said to have accomplished ultimate precept observance, ultimate precept observance.
Good man!
In the past, I was once staying in the great city of CampÄ in the country of Magadha, together with ÅšÄriputra and five hundred disciples.

At that time, there was a hunter chasing after a dove. The dove was frightened and went to ÅšÄriputra's shadow, but still trembled like a banana tree. When it went to my shadow, its body and mind were at ease, and its fear was removed.
Therefore, you should know that the TathÄgata, the World-Honored One, upholds the precepts to the end, and even his shadow still has this power.
Good man!
If one's precepts are not ultimate, one will not be able to attain the stage of Å›rÄvaka or pratyekabuddha, let alone be able to attain supreme, perfect enlightenment.
There are two kinds:
One is for gain, and the other is for the true Dharma.

If one upholds the precepts for gain, one should know that such precepts will not see the Buddha-nature or the TathÄgata. Although one may hear the names of the Buddha-nature and the TathÄgata, one still cannot be said to have seen or heard them.
If one observes the precepts in order to uphold the true Dharma, know that such precepts can see the Buddha-nature and the TathÄgata. This is called seeing with the eyes and also hearing-seeing.
There are two kinds:
One is deeply rooted and difficult to uproot, the other is shallowly rooted and easily moved.
If one is able to cultivate emptiness, signlessness, and wishlessness, this is called having deep roots and being difficult to uproot.
If one does not cultivate these three samÄdhis, even if one cultivates for the sake of the twenty-five existences, this is called having shallow roots and being easily moved.
There are two kinds:
One is for one's own sake, the other is for the sake of sentient beings.
Those who practice for the sake of sentient beings can see the Buddha-nature and the TathÄgata.
There are two kinds of precept-holders:
One is naturally able to uphold the precepts, the other requires the instruction of others.

If one has received the precepts and passes through innumerable eons without violating them, or encounters a bad country, bad friends, bad times, or a bad world, and hears deviant and evil teachings or lives with those of wrong views,
At that time, although there was no precept-receiving ceremony, practicing and upholding as before, without any violation, is called naturally able to uphold.

If one encounters a teacher and receives the precepts through the fourfold proclamation, then one obtains the precepts. Although one has obtained the precepts, one must rely on the preceptor, teachers, fellow students, and good friends' guidance to know how to conduct oneself, listen to the Dharma, expound the Dharma, and be fully equipped with proper deportment. This is called requiring the instruction of others.
Good man!
Those who are able to naturally uphold see the Buddha-nature and the TathÄgata, and this is also called seeing through hearing.
There are two kinds of precepts:
first, the precepts of the Å›rÄvakas, and second, the precepts of the bodhisattvas.
From the initial arousal of the mind until attaining supreme perfect enlightenment, this is called the bodhisattva precepts.
If one contemplates the white bones and attains the fruit of arhatship, this is called the Å›rÄvaka precepts.
If there are those who uphold the Å›rÄvaka precepts, know that they do not see the Buddha-nature and the TathÄgata.
If there are those who uphold the bodhisattva precepts, know that these people will attain supreme, perfect enlightenment, be able to see the Buddha-nature, and attain nirvÄá¹‡a like the TathÄgata.
Bodhisattva Siá¹ƒha-ghosa said:
World-Honored One!
For what causes and conditions do they uphold the precepts?
The Buddha said:
Good man!
It is for the sake of not regretting in the mind.
Why not regret?
It is for the sake of receiving happiness.
Why receive happiness?
It is for the sake of distancing oneself from [afflictions].
Why distance oneself from [afflictions]?
It is for the sake of peace and security.
Why peace and security?
It is for the sake of dhyÄna concentration.
Why dhyÄna concentration?
It is for the sake of true knowledge and insight.
Why for the sake of true knowledge and insight?
It is for the sake of seeing the various faults and afflictions of saá¹ƒsÄra.
Why for the sake of seeing the faults and afflictions of saá¹ƒsÄra?
It is for the sake of the mind not being attached.
Why for the sake of the mind not being attached?
It is for the sake of attaining liberation.
Why is it for the sake of attaining liberation?
It is for the sake of attaining the unsurpassed great nirvÄá¹‡a.
Why is it for the sake of attaining the great nirvÄá¹‡a?
It is for the sake of attaining the dharmas of permanence, bliss, self, and purity.
Why is it for the sake of attaining permanence, bliss, self, and purity?
It is for the sake of attaining non-arising and non-cessation.
Why is it for the sake of attaining non-arising and non-cessation?
It is for the sake of seeing the Buddha-nature.
Therefore, bodhisattvas naturally uphold the ultimate pure precepts.
Good man!
Although the precepts-upholding bhiká¹£us do not make vows seeking a repentant mind, the repentant mind is naturally attained.
Why is it so?
It is because the nature of dharmas is such.
Although they do not seek bliss, detachment, peace, true insight, or see the faults of saá¹ƒsÄra and are not attached to them,
they naturally attain liberation, nirvÄá¹‡a, permanence, bliss, self, purity, non-arising, and non-cessation, and see the Buddha-nature.
Why is it so?
It is because the nature of dharmas is such.
Bodhisattva Siá¹ƒha-ghosa said:
World-Honored One!
If one attains the fruit of non-regret through upholding the precepts, and attains the fruit of nirvana through liberation, then the precepts would have no cause, and nirvana would have no fruit.
If the precepts have no cause, they would be called permanent.
If nirvana has a cause, it would be impermanent.
If so, then nirvana would be something that did not exist before but exists now.
If it did not exist before but exists now, it would be impermanent, just like a burning lamp.
If nirvana is like this, how can it be called self, bliss, and purity?
The Buddha said:ğŸ”½Good man!
Excellent, excellent!
You have planted various roots of goodness with innumerable Buddhas in the past, and are able to ask the TathÄgata about such profound meanings.
Good man!
You ask this way because you have not lost your original intention.
I recall that in the past, more than immeasurable eons ago, in the city of PÄá¹­aliputra, a Buddha appeared in the world, called Suddhodana.
At that time, for three hundred million years, that Buddha expounded this MahÄparinirvÄá¹‡a SÅ«tra. At that time, you and I were together in that assembly, and I asked that Buddha about this matter.
At that time, the TathÄgata, for the sake of sentient beings, entered samÄdhi and had not yet answered this meaning.
Excellent, great being!
You are able to remember such past events.
Listen carefully, listen carefully, I will explain it for you.
Precepts also have a cause, which is listening to the true Dharma.
Listening to the true Dharma also has a cause, which is associating with good friends.
Associating with good friends also has a cause, which is called the mind of faith.
The mind of faith also has a cause, which is twofold:
First, listening to the Dharma, second, contemplating the meaning.
Good man!
The mind of faith is caused by listening to the Dharma, listening to the Dharma is caused by the mind of faith.
These two dharmas are both causes and causal causes, and are both results and resultant results.
Good man!
It is like the Nyagrodha tree, with the branches representing the twelve links, each serving as cause and effect, unable to be separated.
Good man!
Just as ignorance conditions formations, formations condition ignorance.
This ignorance and formations are both causes and causal conditions, and both results and resultant states.
Up to birth conditioning old age and death, old age and death conditioning birth, this birth and old age and death are both causes and causal conditions, and both results and resultant states.
Good man!
Birth can give rise to dharmas, but it cannot give rise to itself. Because it does not give rise to itself, it is given rise to by birth.
The birth of birth does not give rise to itself, but relies on birth to be born.
Therefore, the two births are both causes and causal conditions, and both results and resultant states.
Good man!
Faith and listening to the Dharma are also like this.
Good man!
This result that is not a cause refers to great nirvÄá¹‡a.
Why is it called a result?
Because it is the supreme fruit, the fruit of Å›ramaá¹‡as, the fruit of brÄhmaá¹‡as, the cessation of birth and death, and the destruction of afflictions, it is therefore called the fruit.
Because it is reprimanded by all afflictions, nirvÄá¹‡a is therefore called the fruit. Afflictions are called transgressions.
Good man!
NirvÄá¹‡a has no cause, yet its essence is the fruit.
Why is it so?

Because it is unborn and unceasing, because it is not created, because it is not conditioned, because it is unconditioned, because it is eternally unchanging, because it has no location, and because it has no beginning or end.
Good man!
If nirvÄá¹‡a had a cause, it could not be called nirvÄá¹‡a.
Pan means cause, and parinir means nonexistence. Because it has no cause, it is called nirvÄá¹‡a.
Bodhisattva Siá¹ƒha-ghosa said:
As the Buddha has said, nirvÄá¹‡a has no cause, but this meaning is not so.
If it is said to be nonexistent, then it would conform to six meanings:
First, because it is ultimately non-existent, it is called non-existent, like all dharmas being without self and without what belongs to self.
Second, because it is sometimes non-existent, it is called non-existent, like worldly people saying there is no water in rivers and ponds, and no sun and moon.
Third, because it is small, it is called non-existent, like worldly people saying that food with little salt is called saltless, and sweet drinks with little sweetness are called unsweet.
Fourth, because it is not accepted, it is called non-existent, like a chandala who cannot accept and uphold the dharma of a brahmin, and is therefore called a non-brahmin.

Fifth, because it accepts evil dharmas, it is called non-existent, like worldly people saying that those who accept evil dharmas are not called Å›ramaá¹‡as or brahmins, and are therefore called non-Å›ramaá¹‡as and non-brahmins.
Sixth, because it is not opposed, it is called non-existent, like calling the absence of white black, and calling the absence of illumination non-illumination.
World-Honored One!
Nirvana is also like this. Sometimes it has no causes, and therefore it is called nirvana.
The Buddha said:
Good man!
Why don't you use the ultimate non-existence to illustrate nirvana, as you have explained these six meanings?
How can you take something that sometimes exists and sometimes does not?
Good man!
The essence of nirvana is ultimately without causes, just like the non-existence of self and what belongs to the self.
Good man!
The worldly dharmas and nirvana are never mutually corresponding. Therefore, the six things cannot be used as analogies.
Good man!

All dharmas are completely without self, but this nirvana truly has self. For this reason, nirvana has no causes, but its essence is the result. It is a cause but not a result, and is called buddha-nature.
Because it is not born from causes, it is a cause but not a result.
It is not called a result because it is not the result of a Å›ramaá¹‡a.
Why is it called a cause?
Because it is the cause of realization.
Good man!
There are two kinds of causes:
The first is the cause of birth, and the second is the cause of illumination.
That which can give rise to dharmas is called the cause of birth;
Because a lamp can illuminate objects, it is called the cause of illumination.
Afflictions and bonds are called the cause of birth;
The parents of sentient beings are called the cause of illumination.
Seeds and so forth are called the cause of birth;
Earth, water, manure, and so forth are called the cause of illumination.
There is also the cause of birth, namely the six perfections and anuttara-samyak-sambodhi.
There is also the cause of illumination, namely buddha-nature and anuttara-samyak-sambodhi.
There is also the cause of illumination, namely the six perfections and buddha-nature.
There is also the cause of birth, namely the Å›Å«raá¹ƒgama-samÄdhi and anuttara-samyak-sambodhi.
There is also the cause of illumination, namely the eightfold right path and anuttara-samyak-sambodhi.
There is also the cause of birth, namely the faith and the six perfections.
Bodhisattva Lion's Roar said:
World-Honored One!
As the Buddha has said, seeing the TathÄgata and Buddha-nature, what does this mean?
World-Honored One!

The TathÄgata's body has no characteristics, is neither long nor short, neither white nor black, has no location, does not abide in the three realms, is not a conditioned appearance, and is not cognized by the eye consciousness. How can it be seen?
Buddha-nature is also like this.
The Buddha said:
Good man!
The Buddha's body is of two kinds:
One is permanent, the other impermanent.
The impermanent is for the sake of liberating all sentient beings, expediently manifesting, which is called seeing with the eyes.
The permanent is the liberated body of the TathÄgata, World-Honored One, which is also called seeing with the eyes and also called seeing with the ears.
Buddha-nature is also twofold:
One is visible, the other invisible.
The visible is for bodhisattvas of the tenth stage and the Buddhas, World-Honored Ones.
The invisible refers to all sentient beings.
The visible refers to the bodhisattvas of the ten abodes and the buddhas, who see with their eyes the buddha-nature possessed by sentient beings.
The audible refers to all sentient beings and the bodhisattvas of the nine abodes, who hear of the buddha-nature and the body of the TathÄgata.
There are two kinds:
the visible and the invisible.
The visible refers to the liberation of the TathÄgata, and the invisible refers to the TathÄgata's permanent severing of all forms.
Buddha-nature is of two kinds:
the visible and the invisible.

The visible refers to supreme, perfect enlightenment, and the invisible refers to ordinary beings up to the bodhisattvas of the ten abodes. The bodhisattvas of the ten abodes see it indistinctly, so it is called invisible.
Good man!
Buddha-nature is of two kinds:
the visible and the invisible.
The visible refers to the buddhas and bodhisattvas, and the invisible refers to all sentient beings.
Form is what is seen by the eyes, non-form is what is seen by hearing.
Buddha-nature is neither internal nor external. Although it is neither internal nor external, it is not lost or destroyed, and therefore it is said that all sentient beings possess buddha-nature.
Bodhisattva Siá¹ƒha-ghosa said:
World-Honored One!
As the Buddha has said, all sentient beings possess buddha-nature, like milk containing curd.
The vajra-warriors and buddhas' buddha-nature is like pure ghee. Why did the Buddha say that buddha-nature is neither internal nor external?
The Buddha said:
Good man!
I also do not say that milk contains curd. Because curd is produced from milk, I say it contains curd.
World-Honored One!
All produced dharmas have their own time periods.
Good man!
At the time of milk, there is no curd, nor raw or ripened ghee. All sentient beings also call it milk. Therefore, I say that milk does not contain curd.
If it exists, why can't it have two kinds of names?
Like a person with two abilities, called a goldsmith and an ironsmith.
At the time of curd, there is no milk, raw butter, cooked butter, or ghee. Sentient beings also call it curd, not milk, not raw or cooked butter, or ghee. It is also like this.
Good man!
There are two kinds of causes:
The first is the direct cause, and the second is the contributory cause.
The direct cause is like milk producing curd, and the contributory cause is like yeast and warmth.
Because it arises from milk, it is said that curd exists in milk.
Bodhisattva Siá¹ƒha-ghosa said:
World-Honored One!
If milk has no nature of curd, and horns also have none, why doesn't it arise from horns?
Good man!
Horns also produce curd.
Why is it so?
I also say that contributory causes are of two kinds:
The first is yeast, and the second is warmth.
because the nature of horns is warm, it can also produce yogurt.
Shizihou said:
World-Honored One!
If horns can produce yogurt, why do those seeking yogurt seek milk and not take horns?
The Buddha said:
Good man!
Therefore, I speak of the correct cause and the conditional cause.
Bodhisattva Shizihou said:
If it is so that milk originally has no nature of yogurt, but now it does,
why does milk originally have no Ämalaka tree? Why does it not grow?
Because both are originally nonexistent.
Good man!
Milk can also produce an Ämalaka tree.
If one pours milk on it, it will grow five feet in one night. For this reason, I speak of two causes.
Good man!
If all dharmas are produced by one cause, one can ask why milk cannot produce an Ämalaka tree.
Good man!
It is like the four great elements, which serve as causes and conditions for all forms, yet the forms are each different and not the same.
For this reason, an Ämalaka tree does not grow from milk.
World-Honored One!
As the Buddha has said, there are two causes: the direct cause and the contributory cause.
What is the Buddha-nature of sentient beings?
Good man!
The Buddha-nature of sentient beings is also of two causes:
First, the direct cause, which refers to all sentient beings; second, the contributory cause, which refers to the six pÄramitÄs.
Siá¹ƒha said:
World-Honored One!
I now definitely know that milk has the nature of curds.
Why is it so?
Because I see that people in the world who seek curds only take milk and never take water. Therefore, I know that milk has the nature of curds.
Good man!
Your question is not reasonable.
Why is it so?
All sentient beings want to see their own facial reflections, so they take up a knife.
The lion's roar said:
World-Honored One!
For this reason, milk has the nature of curd.
If the knife has no facial reflection, why take up a knife?
The Buddha said:
Good man!
If this knife definitely has a facial reflection, why is it upside down? When held vertically, it is seen as long, and when held horizontally, it is seen as wide.
If it is one's own face, why is it seen as long?
If it is the face of another, how can it be called one's own facial reflection?
If it is caused by one's own face to see another's face, why is the reflection of an ass or horse's face not seen?
The lion's roar said:
World-Honored One!
The light of the eyes reaches there, so the face is seen as long.
The Buddha said:
Good man!
The light of the eyes truly does not reach there.
Why is this?
Because near and far are seen simultaneously, and because objects between [the eyes and the reflection] are not seen.
Good man!
If light reaches there and can be seen, all sentient beings would see fire, why is it not burning?
If a person sees a white object from afar, they should not doubt whether it is a crane,
a banner,
a person,
or a tree?
If light reaches there, how can one see objects in crystal, or fish and stones in a deep pool?
If it does not reach and see, why can one see objects in crystal, but not the colors outside the wall?
Therefore, if one says that the light of the eyes reaches there and sees the long one, this meaning is not so.
Good man!
As you say, milk has curds, why is it that the seller of milk only takes the price of milk and does not charge for curds?
The seller of a pregnant mare only takes the price of the mare and does not charge for the foal.
Good man!
People in the world, because they have no children, seek to marry a wife.
If the wife becomes pregnant, one cannot say it is a girl.
If you say that because a woman has the nature of having a child, she should be married, that is not so.
Why is it so?
If she has the nature of having a child, she should also have the nature of having grandchildren. If she has grandchildren, then she is a brother.
Why is it so?
Because they are born from the same womb.
Therefore, I say that a woman does not have the nature of having a child.
If there is the nature of curd in milk, why is the five flavors not seen at the same time?
If there is the five zhang tall niqiu tree in a tree seed, why is the difference in sprouts, stems, branches, leaves, flowers, and fruits not seen at the same time?
Good man!
The color of milk is different, the taste is different, the fruit is different, up to ghee is also like this, how can it be said that milk has the nature of curd?
Good man!
It is like a person who will take ghee tomorrow, but now already has a dislike for its smell.
If it is said that curd definitely exists in milk, it is also like this.
Good man!
It is like a person who uses a brush, paper, and ink to create a written character.
But originally there were no characters on the paper, and because they were originally non-existent, they are formed through conditions.
If they were originally existent, why would they need many conditions?
It is like blue and yellow combining to form the color green. You should know that these two originally have no conditional nature.
If they were originally existent, why would they need to combine?
Good man!
It is like sentient beings who obtain life through food, but this food is actually devoid of life.
If it were originally alive, then before eating, the food should be alive.
Good man!
All dharmas are originally devoid of inherent nature. For this reason, I spoke this verse:
Originally non-existent, now existent; originally existent, now non-existent.
Dharmas existing in the three times do not exist.
Good man!
All dharmas arise due to conditions and cease due to conditions.
Good man!
If all sentient beings possess buddha-nature within, all sentient beings should have a buddha's body, just like me now.
The buddha-nature of sentient beings is unbroken, indestructible, unpulled, ungrasped, unfettered, and unbound.
Just as there is space within all sentient beings, all sentient beings possess space, because it is unobstructed, and each does not see for themselves that there is this space.

If sentient beings were without space, there would be no coming and going, walking, standing, sitting, lying down, no birth, no growth. For this reason, I say in the sutras that all sentient beings possess the realm of space. The realm of space is called space.
The buddha-nature of sentient beings is also like this. Bodhisattvas of the tenth stage can see a little of it, like a vajra jewel.
Good man!
The buddha-nature of sentient beings is the realm of the buddhas, and is not known by the hearers and solitary realizers.
All sentient beings do not see the Buddha-nature, and therefore they are always bound by afflictions and flow through birth and death.
Because they see the Buddha-nature, the afflictions of the bonds cannot bind them, they are liberated from birth and death, and attain great nirvÄá¹‡a.
Lion's Roar Bodhisattva said:
World-Honored One!
All sentient beings have the Buddha-nature, like the nature of curd in milk.
If milk has no nature of curd, why did the Buddha say there are two kinds of causes: the first is the direct cause, and the second is the contributory cause?
The contributory causes are yeast and warmth.
Space has no nature, and therefore it has no contributory cause.
The Buddha said:
Good man!
If it is certain that milk has the nature of curd, why is a contributory cause necessary?
Lion's Roar Bodhisattva said:
World-Honored One!
Because it has the nature, a contributory cause is necessary.
Why is this?
In order to make it clear, the contributory cause is the revealing cause.
World-Honored One!
It is like there being objects in the dark before, and in order to see them, one uses a lamp to illuminate them.
If they did not exist before, what would the lamp illuminate?
It is like a pot existing in clay, so it needs people, water, a wheel, a rope, a stick, etc. as revealing causes.
It is like the seeds of a ficus tree needing soil, water, and manure as revealing causes.
It is the same with curds in milk, also needing revealing causes to be made.
Therefore, even though the nature existed before, it still needs revealing causes, and only then can it be seen. For this reason, it is certain that curds exist in milk before.
Good man!
If it is certain that curds exist in milk, then it is the revealing cause.
If it is the revealing cause, then what else is needed to reveal it?
Good man!
If the revealing cause is by nature revealing, then it should always reveal itself;
if it cannot reveal itself, how can it reveal others?
If you say the illuminating cause has two natures:
One is self-illumination, the other is illumination of others, this is not so.
Why is it so?
How can a single illuminating cause have two?
If there are two, then milk should also be two.
If there are no two aspects in milk, how can the illuminating cause alone have two?
Shizihou said:
World-Honored One!
Just as worldly people say, 'I am with eight people,' the illuminating cause is also like this, self-illuminating and illuminating others.
The Buddha said:
Good man!
If the illuminating cause is like this, then it is not an illuminating cause.
Why is it so?
The counter can count its own color and the color of others, so it can be said to be eight.
But this color nature itself has no illuminating aspect. Because it has no illuminating aspect, it must rely on the nature of wisdom to count itself and others.
Therefore, the illuminating cause cannot illuminate itself, nor can it illuminate others.
Good man!
If all sentient beings possess buddha-nature, why do they cultivate immeasurable merits?
If you say cultivation is the revealing cause, it is the same as the destruction of curds.
If you say the effect definitely exists within the cause, then morality, concentration, and wisdom would not increase.
I see in the world that people originally have no morality, concentration, or wisdom, but gradually increase them after receiving them from a teacher.
If you say the teacher's teaching is the revealing cause, when the teacher teaches, the recipient has not yet attained morality, concentration, or wisdom.
If it is the revealing [cause], it should reveal what has not yet existed. How can it then reveal morality, concentration, and wisdom to make them increase?
Bodhisattva Siá¹ƒha-ghosa said:
World-Honored One!
If the revealing cause does not exist, how can it be said that milk exists because curds exist?
Good man!
There are three kinds of answers to objections in the world:
1. The first is the revolving answer, such as the previous statement, 'Why is it called morality?'
Because of not regretting, up to in order to attain great nirvana.
Second, answering in silence. As when a brahman came and asked me, Am I permanent?
I was silent at that time.
Third, answering with doubt. As in this sutra, if the revealing cause has two, why can't milk have two?
Good man!
I now give a turning answer.

As worldly people say, There is milk and there is curd because it is certain to be obtained, therefore it can be called where there is milk there is curd. Buddha-nature is also like this. Where there are sentient beings there is Buddha-nature, because it will be seen.
Shizihou said:
World-Honored One!
The meaning explained by the Buddha is not so.
The past has already ceased, and the future has not yet arrived. How can it be called existent?
If it is said that what will be named is called existent, this meaning is not so.
As worldly people, seeing no children, say there are no children.
If all sentient beings do not have buddha-nature, why do you say that all sentient beings have buddha-nature?
The Buddha said:
Good man!

The past is called existence. For example, when an orange seed sprouts, the seed disappears, but the sprout is still sweet, and even when it grows into a fruit, the taste is the same. Only when it ripens does it become sour.
Good man!

This sour taste is not in the seed, sprout, or even the growing fruit, but it arises when it reaches maturity. The sour taste was originally non-existent but now exists. Although it was originally non-existent but now exists, it is not without a basis.
This original seed, although past, is still called existent.
For this reason, the past is called existence.
How is the future also called existence?
For example, if someone plants sesame seeds, someone may ask:
'Why plant this?'
They may reply:
'Because there is oil.'
' In fact, the oil has not yet been produced. When the sesame seeds are ripe, they are harvested, roasted, pounded, and pressed, and only then is the oil obtained.
You should know that this person is not speaking falsely.
For this reason, it is called 'future existence.'
How is it also called 'past existence'?
Good man!
It is like a person who secretly slanders the king in private for many years, and the king only hears about it later.
Having heard it, he immediately asks:
'Why did you slander me?'
He replies:
'Great king!
I did not slander you.
Why is that?
The slanderer has already perished.'
The king says:
'The slanderer and my body both exist. How can you say he has perished?'
Because of this, he loses his life.
Good man!
Although these two are actually non-existent, the result does not perish. This is called 'past existence.'
How is it also called 'future existence'?
It is like a person who goes to a potter and asks if he has any pots.
The potter replies that he has pots.
But the potter actually does not have any pots yet, because he has clay, he says he has pots. You should know that this person is not speaking falsely.
Milk contains curd, and the Buddha-nature of sentient beings is also like this.
If you want to see the Buddha-nature, you should observe the time and form. Therefore, I say that all sentient beings have Buddha-nature, and it is not false.
Siá¹ƒha said:
If all sentient beings do not have Buddha-nature, how can they attain supreme, perfect enlightenment?
Because of the correct cause, it causes sentient beings to attain supreme, perfect enlightenment.
What is the correct cause?
It is called Buddha-nature.
World-Honored One!
If the nyagrodha seed does not have a nyagrodha tree, why is it called a nyagrodha seed and not a khadira seed?
World-Honored One!
Just as the surname Gautama cannot be called the surname Ä€ditya, and the surname Ä€ditya also cannot be called the surname Gautama.
The nyagrodha seed is also like this, it cannot be called a khadira seed, and the khadira seed cannot be called a nyagrodha seed.
Just as the World-Honored One cannot abandon the Gautama clan, the buddha-nature of sentient beings is also like this. For this reason, one should know that all sentient beings possess buddha-nature.
The Buddha said:
Good man!
If you say that the seed has a nyagrodha tree, this is not so.
If it does, why is it not seen?
Good man!
It is like worldly things that cannot be seen due to causes and conditions.
What are the causes and conditions?
It is like the tracks of a bird in the sky, which cannot be seen from a distance.
It is like the eyelashes of a person, which cannot be seen up close.ğŸ”½It is like someone with impaired faculties, who cannot see due to decay.
It is like someone with a distracted mind, who cannot see due to disordered thoughts.
It is like a tiny particle, which cannot be seen due to its subtlety.
It is like stars above the clouds, which cannot be seen due to obstruction.ğŸ”½It is like sesame seeds in a pile of rice, which cannot be seen due to their abundance.
It is like beans in a pile of beans, which cannot be seen due to their similarity.
The nyagrodha tree is not the same as these eight kinds of causes. If it exists, why is it not seen?
If it is said that it is not seen because it is subtle and obstructed, this is not reasonable.
Why is it so?
Because the characteristics of the tree are coarse.
If it is said to be subtle by nature, how can it grow?
If it is said that it cannot be seen because it is obstructed, it should always be unseen.
Originally without coarse characteristics, now it is seen as coarse.
You should know that this coarseness originally has no nature. Originally, the nature of seeing did not exist, but now it can be seen. You should know that this seeing also originally has no nature.
The sprout is also like this. Originally, there was no tree, but now it exists. What fault is there?
Siá¹ƒha said:
As the Buddha has said, there are two kinds of causes:
First, the direct cause; second, the revealing cause.
Because the seeds of the nyagrodha tree are made into a revealing cause by earth, water, and manure, the subtle becomes coarse.
The Buddha said:
Good man!
If it originally existed, what need is there for a revealing cause?
If it originally has no nature, what is there to reveal?
If the nyagrodha tree originally has no coarse appearance, and because of the revealing cause it gives rise to coarseness, why does it not give rise to a khadira tree?
Because both are originally non-existent.
Good man!
If the subtle is not seen, the coarse should be visible.
It is like a single dust mote, which cannot be seen, but many dust motes gathered together should be visible.
In this way, the coarse should be visible within the seed.
Why is this?

Because within it there are already sprouts, stems, flowers, and fruits, and within each fruit there are countless seeds, and within each seed there are countless trees. Therefore it is called coarse, and because it has this coarseness, it should be visible.
Good man!
If the seed of a nyagrodha tree has the nature of a nyagrodha and gives rise to a tree, one can see that the seed is burned by fire. In this way, the nature of burning should also originally exist;
if it originally existed, the tree should not grow.
If all dharmas originally have arising and ceasing, why do they not arise and cease at the same time?
For this reason, one should know that there is no nature.
Bodhisattva Siá¹ƒha-ghosa said:
World-Honored One!
If the nyagrodha seed originally had no nature of a tree and yet produced a tree, why would it not produce oil?
Because both are lacking.
Good man,
in this way, the seed is also able to produce oil, although it originally lacks that nature, because of conditions it has it.
Shizihou said:
Why is it not called sesame oil?
Good man,
because it is not sesame.
Good man,
just as fire arises from conditions and water arises from conditions, although they both arise from conditions, they cannot mutually exist.
The nyagrodha seed and sesame oil are also like this. Although they both arise from conditions, they do not mutually produce each other.
The nyagrodha seed has the nature to cure cold,
while sesame oil has the nature to cure wind.
Good man,
it is like sugarcane, which arises from conditions.
Although molasses and black honey are both produced from the same cause, their colors and appearances are different. Molasses cures heat, while black honey cures cold.
Bodhisattva Siá¹ƒha-nÄda said:
World-Honored One!

If milk does not inherently have the nature of curd, sesame does not have the nature of oil, a banyan tree seed does not have the nature of a tree, clay does not have the nature of a pot, and all sentient beings do not have the nature of a buddha, as the Buddha previously said that all sentient beings possess the buddha-nature, therefore they should attain supreme perfect enlightenment, this meaning is not so.
Why is it so?
Humans and gods do not have the nature.
Because they lack the nature, humans can become gods, and gods can become humans, due to karmic causes and conditions, not because of their nature.
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas attain supreme perfect enlightenment due to karmic causes and conditions.
If all sentient beings possess buddha-nature, why do icchantikas sever their wholesome roots and fall into hell?
If the bodhi mind is the buddha-nature, icchantikas should not be able to sever it;
if it can be severed, how can it be said that the buddha-nature is permanent?
If it is impermanent, it cannot be called the buddha-nature.
If all sentient beings possess buddha-nature, why are they called those who have just aroused the mind?
How can it be said that some are still learning and some have gone beyond learning?
Those who are still learning should know that they do not have buddha-nature.
World-Honored One!

Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas single-mindedly aspire to supreme, perfect enlightenment. Out of great kindness and compassion, they see the faults of birth, old age, sickness, death, and afflictions. They contemplate the great nirvÄá¹‡a, which is free from birth, old age, death, and the afflictions. They have faith in the Three Jewels and in the fruits of karma. They uphold the precepts. Such dharmas are called the buddha-nature.
If there is buddha-nature apart from these dharmas, what need is there for these dharmas to serve as causes and conditions?
World-Honored One!

Just as milk does not require conditions and will certainly turn into yogurt, fresh butter is not like that and must await causes and conditions, namely human effort, a water bottle, and a churning rope.
It is the same for sentient beings. If there is buddha-nature, one should attain anuttarÄ-samyak-saá¹ƒbodhi apart from causes and conditions.
If it is definitely existent, why do practitioners see the suffering of the three evil destinies, birth, old age, sickness, and death, and give rise to a retrogressive mind?
They should not need to cultivate the six pÄramitÄs and should immediately attain anuttarÄ-samyak-saá¹ƒbodhi, just as milk does not rely on conditions to turn into yogurt.
However, it is not that one attains anuttarÄ-samyak-saá¹ƒbodhi without relying on the six pÄramitÄs. For this reason, one should know that sentient beings all lack buddha-nature.
As the Buddha said earlier that the Sangha Jewel is permanent, if it is permanent, then it is not impermanent;
If it is not impermanent, how can one attain supreme, perfect enlightenment?
If the Saá¹…gha is permanent, why do you say that all sentient beings possess buddha-nature?
World-Honored One!

If sentient beings from the beginning have neither the mind of enlightenment nor the mind of supreme, perfect enlightenment, but only later have them, then the buddha-nature of sentient beings should also be like this, not existing before but existing later.
For this reason, all sentient beings should be without buddha-nature.
The Buddha said:
Excellent, excellent!
Good man!
You have long known the meaning of buddha-nature, but you asked this question for the sake of sentient beings.
All sentient beings truly possess buddha-nature.
You said that if sentient beings possess buddha-nature, they should not have the initial arousal of the mind. Good man!
The mind is not buddha-nature.
Why is it so?
Because the mind is impermanent, while buddha-nature is permanent.
You say, why is there a retreating mind?
In reality, there is no retreating mind.
If the mind were to retreat, one would never be able to attain supreme perfect enlightenment. Because of the delay in attainment, it is called retreating.
This mind of enlightenment is truly not the Buddha-nature.
Why is it so?
Because the icchantikas, who have severed their wholesome roots, fall into hell.
If the mind of enlightenment were the Buddha-nature, then the icchantikas would not be called icchantikas.
The mind of enlightenment could also not be called impermanent.
Therefore, it is certain that the mind of enlightenment is truly not the Buddha-nature.
Good man!
You say, if sentient beings have Buddha-nature, they should not rely on conditions, like milk turning into curd. This reasoning is incorrect.
Why is it so?
If it is said that the five conditions produce fresh butter, one should know that the Buddha-nature is also like this.
It is like various stones, some are gold, some are silver, some are copper, some are iron, all receiving the four great elements, with one name and one substance, but what they produce is different.

It must rely on various conditions, the blessings and virtues of sentient beings, the work of the furnace and forge, and then it is produced. Therefore, you should know that originally there is no nature of gold.
The Buddha-nature of sentient beings is not called the Buddha, but by the combination of various merits and conditions, one can see the Buddha-nature and then attain Buddhahood.
You say that all sentient beings have Buddha-nature, why can't they see it?
This reasoning is not correct.
Why is it so?
It is because the various conditions have not yet come together.
Good man!
For this reason, I speak of two causes, the direct cause and the contributory cause.
The direct cause is called Buddha-nature, and the contributory cause is the arising of the aspiration for enlightenment.
By these two causes and conditions, one attains supreme perfect enlightenment, like extracting gold from stone.
Good man!
You say that the Saá¹…gha is permanent, and that all sentient beings have no buddha-nature. Good man!
The Saá¹…gha is called harmony, and there are two kinds of harmony:
The first is worldly harmony, and the second is ultimate harmony.
The worldly harmony is called the Saá¹…gha of Å›rÄvakas, and the ultimate harmony is called the Saá¹…gha of bodhisattvas.
The worldly Saá¹…gha is impermanent, but buddha-nature is permanent.
Just as buddha-nature is permanent, so too is the ultimate Saá¹…gha.

Furthermore, there is a Saá¹…gha called the harmony of the Dharma. The harmony of the Dharma refers to the twelve divisions of the scriptures. The twelve divisions of the scriptures are permanent, and therefore I say that the Dharma and the Saá¹…gha are permanent.
Good man!

The Saá¹…gha is called harmony, and harmony refers to the twelve links of dependent arising. The twelve links of dependent arising also have buddha-nature, and the twelve links of dependent arising are permanent.
Buddha-nature is also like this. Therefore I say that the Saá¹…gha has buddha-nature.
Moreover, the Saá¹…gha refers to the harmony of all buddhas. Therefore I say that the Saá¹…gha has buddha-nature.
Good man!
You say that if sentient beings have buddha-nature, why are there those who regress and those who do not regress?
Listen carefully, listen carefully!
I will explain it to you in detail.
Good man!
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas have thirteen dharmas that lead to regression.
What are the thirteen?
First, a mind of disbelief;
Second, a mind of non-action;
Third, a mind of doubt;
Fourth, being stingy with one's body and wealth;
Fifth, giving rise to great fear in nirvÄá¹‡a, thinking how can it cause sentient beings to be eternally extinguished;
Sixth, a mind that cannot bear;
Seventh, a mind that is not pliable;
Eighth, sorrow;
Ninth, unhappiness;
Tenth, negligence;
Eleventh, belittling oneself;
Twelfth, seeing one's afflictions as indestructible;
Thirteenth, not delighting in progressing towards the Dharma of bodhi.
Good man!
These are called the thirteen dharmas that cause bodhisattvas to regress from bodhi.
There are also six dharmas that destroy the bodhi mind.
What are the six?

First, being stingy with the Dharma; second, giving rise to unwholesome thoughts towards sentient beings; third, associating with bad friends; fourth, lacking diligence; fifth, being arrogant and conceited; sixth, engaging in worldly affairs.
Such six dharmas can destroy the bodhi mind.
Good man!
There are people who hear that the buddhas, the world-honored ones, are the teachers of humans and gods, supreme among sentient beings, incomparable, superior to Å›rÄvakas and pratyekabuddhas.
With the clear Dharma eye, they see the Dharma without obstruction and are able to deliver sentient beings from the great sea of suffering. Having heard this, they then give rise to a great vow.
If there are such people in the world, I too shall attain this.
For these causes and conditions, they give rise to the mind of supreme, perfect enlightenment, or they give rise to the mind of enlightenment because they are taught by others.
Or they hear that bodhisattvas cultivate ascetic practices for incalculable eons, and only then attain supreme, perfect enlightenment.
Having heard this, they think:
I am now unable to endure such ascetic practices, so how can I attain it?
Therefore, there is regression.
Good sons!
There are also five dharmas that cause regression from the mind of enlightenment.
What are the five?

First, delighting in going forth among non-Buddhists; second, not cultivating the mind of great compassion; third, delighting in seeking the faults of Dharma teachers; fourth, always delighting in dwelling in saá¹ƒsÄra; fifth, not delighting in receiving, upholding, reading, reciting, copying, and explaining the twelve divisions of the scriptures. These are called the five dharmas that cause regression from the mind of enlightenment.
There are also two dharmas that cause regression from the mind of enlightenment.
What are the two?
First, they delight in the five desires; second, they are unable to respectfully revere the Three Jewels.
For these and other causes and conditions, they regress from the mind of enlightenment.
Why is it also called the non-regressing mind?

There are people who hear that the Buddha can deliver sentient beings from birth, old age, sickness, and death, and without consulting a teacher, they naturally cultivate and attain supreme, perfect enlightenment.
If the path to enlightenment can be attained, I will cultivate and surely attain it.
For these causes and conditions, they give rise to the mind of enlightenment. The merit they create, whether much or little, they all dedicate to supreme, perfect enlightenment, making this vow:

'May I always be able to closely attend the Buddhas and the Buddha's disciples, always hear the profound Dharma, and have all five faculties complete. If I encounter suffering and difficulty, may I not lose this mind.'
May the Buddhas and their disciples always give rise to a joyful mind towards me, and be endowed with the five wholesome roots.

If sentient beings were to cut up my body, severing my hands, feet, head, eyes, and limbs, I would give rise to a great compassionate mind towards them, deeply rejoicing, thinking: 'These people are increasing the causes and conditions for my enlightenment. If it were not for them, how could I accomplish supreme, perfect enlightenment?'
And I would make this vow:

'May I not obtain a body without sexual organs, a body with two sexual organs, or a woman's body. May I not be subject to others, not encounter a bad master, not belong to a bad king, not be born in a bad country. If I obtain a good body with a pure family lineage, with abundant wealth and treasures, may I not give rise to arrogance. May I always hear the twelve divisions of the scriptures, uphold and recite them, copy them, and explain them.
If I expound them for the sake of sentient beings, may those who receive them respectfully believe without doubt, and may they never give rise to evil thoughts towards me.
I would rather hear little and understand much of the meaning, than wish to hear much and not understand the meaning.

Wish to take the mind as the teacher, not the mind as the teacher, and do not associate with evil in body, speech, and mind. Able to bestow peace and happiness to all sentient beings, the body, precepts, mind, and wisdom are immovable like a mountain. Wishing to uphold the unsurpassed true Dharma, do not be stingy with one's body, life, and wealth.

Do not use impure things to create meritorious karma. Sustain oneself with the right livelihood, and the mind is free from deceit. Always remember kindness, and repay even small kindnesses with great deeds.

Be well-versed in the skills and arts of the world, and understand the local languages of sentient beings. Read, recite, and copy the twelve divisions of the scriptures, and do not give rise to a lazy or indolent mind.
If sentient beings are not inclined to listen, use skillful means to guide them, causing them to enjoy listening.

Always gentle and soft-spoken, not uttering evil words, able to reconcile discordant assemblies, relieving those who are fearful and terrified, in times of famine causing abundance, in times of disease becoming a great physician king, with freely available wealth and treasures for medicine and supplies, curing all the sick.
In the age of warfare, with great strength cutting off the remaining harm, leaving none behind.

Able to cut off various fears of sentient beings, namely, such fears as death, imprisonment, beating, water, fire, kings, thieves, poverty, breaking precepts, bad reputation, and bad destinies, all of which are to be eliminated.

Have deep respect for parents, teachers, and elders, and give rise to great compassion towards enemies and those who are disliked. Always cultivate the six recollections, the door of emptiness samÄdhi, the twelve links of dependent origination, the observation of arising and ceasing, the exhalation and inhalation of breath, celestial practices, brahma practices, and noble practices, the vajra samÄdhi, the Å›Å«raá¹ƒgama samÄdhi, and in places where there are no Three Jewels, allow me to attain a tranquil mind by myself.
If the body and mind experience great suffering, do not lose the unsurpassed bodhi mind, and do not be content with the mind of Å›rÄvakas and pratyekabuddhas.

In places where there are no Three Jewels, always leave the home life in non-Buddhist teachings, in order to destroy wrong views and not practice their path, attain mastery over the Dharma, and attain mastery over the mind.

Clearly see the faults in conditioned phenomena, and cause me to fear the fruits of the paths of the two vehicles, like one who cherishes life fears giving up the body, and for the sake of sentient beings, happily dwell in the three evil destinies.
Just as all sentient beings delight in the Heaven of the Thirty-three, for the sake of each person they would undergo the sufferings of hell for immeasurable eons without a regretful mind.
Seeing others gain benefits, they do not give rise to jealous thoughts, but always give rise to joy as if they themselves had obtained happiness.

If they encounter the Three Jewels, they should make offerings of clothing, food and drink, bedding, dwellings, medicine, lamps, flowers, incense, music, banners, canopies, and the seven precious metals.
If they receive the Buddha's precepts, they should firmly uphold them and never give rise to thoughts of transgression.

If they hear of the bodhisattvas' difficult practices and austerities, their minds will be filled with joy and they will not give rise to regret or resentment. They will recognize their past lives and will never create the karma of greed, anger, or delusion.
They will not accumulate causes and conditions for the sake of karmic rewards, and will not give rise to attachment to present happiness.
Good man!
If there are those who can make such vows, they are called bodhisattvas who will never lose the mind of enlightenment.

They are also called benefactors, able to see the TathÄgata, clearly understand buddha-nature, able to tame sentient beings and liberate them from birth and death, able to well protect and uphold the unsurpassed true Dharma, and able to fully attain the six perfections.
Good man!
For this reason, the mind of non-retrogression is not called buddha-nature.
Good man!
You cannot say that all sentient beings do not have buddha-nature because of having a mind of retrogression.

It is like two people who both hear that in another place there is a mountain of the seven treasures, and on the mountain there is clear spring with a sweet and delicious taste. If one can reach it, they will forever end poverty. If one drinks the water, they will increase their lifespan to ten thousand years. However, the road is far and dangerous with many difficulties.
At that time, the two people both wanted to go together. One person prepared various provisions, while the other went empty-handed without bringing anything.
They went forward together and on the way met a person who brought many treasures and was fully equipped with the seven treasures.
The two people then went forward and asked:
'Sir!
Are there really seven jeweled mountains in that land?
' The man replied:

'It is true, not false. I have already obtained the treasures, drunk the water, but the road is perilous, there are many robbers, the sand is salty and thorny, and there is little water and grass. Thousands have gone, but very few have reached their destination.
' Having heard this, one person immediately regretted it and said:
'Since the road is so far and the difficulties are not one, those who go are countless, but those who reach their destination are few. How can I possibly get there?
I now barely make enough to get by. If I set out on this road, I may lose my life. If my life is not preserved, how can I have long life?
' Another person said:
'If someone can go, I can also go.
If I can reach my destination, I will be able to fulfill my wish, collect precious treasures, and drink the sweet water.
If I cannot reach it, I will make it my goal to die.ğŸ”½'

At that time, one of the two men regretted and returned, while the other continued on to the mountain, obtained much wealth and treasures, drank the water as he wished, took many provisions, returned to his home, supported his parents, and provided for his relatives.
At that time, the one who regretted and returned saw this and a thought of regret arose in his mind:
He has gone and returned, why should I stay?
He then immediately prepared to travel and set out on the road.

The mountain of the seven treasures is a metaphor for the great nirvana, the sweet water is a metaphor for the buddha-nature, the two men are a metaphor for the two bodhisattvas who first give rise to the aspiration for enlightenment, the dangerous road is a metaphor for birth and death, the person encountered is a metaphor for the World-Honored Buddha, the robbers are a metaphor for the four demons, the salt and thorns are a metaphor for the afflictions, the lack of water and grass is a metaphor for not cultivating the path to enlightenment, the one who returns is a metaphor for the bodhisattva who regresses, and the one who goes straight is a metaphor for the bodhisattva who does not regress.
Good man!

The Buddha-nature of sentient beings is eternally abiding and unchanging, just like that dangerous road. One cannot say that because a person regrets and returns, the road becomes impermanent. The Buddha-nature is also like this.
Good man!
In the path of enlightenment, there is ultimately no one who turns back.
Good man!

It is like the one who regretted before. Seeing that his former companions had obtained treasures and returned, with power and freedom, making offerings to their parents and supporting their relatives, enjoying much comfort and happiness.

Having seen this, a hot feeling arose in his heart, and he immediately prepared again and went back the way he came, not sparing his life, enduring various difficulties, and eventually reaching the mountain of the seven treasures. The bodhisattva who turns back is also like this.
Good man!

All sentient beings will definitely attain supreme perfect enlightenment. For this reason, I say in the sutras that all sentient beings, even those who commit the five heinous crimes, violate the four grave prohibitions, and are icchantikas, all have Buddha-nature.
The lion's roar said:
World-Honored One!
How are there bodhisattvas who regress and do not regress?
The Buddha said: Good man!

If there are bodhisattvas who cultivate the causes and conditions of the thirty-two marks of a TathÄgata, they are called non-regressing and are called bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas, called unmoving, called compassionate to all sentient beings, called superior to all Å›rÄvakas and pratyekabuddhas, called irreversible.
Good man!

If bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas uphold the precepts without moving and their mind of giving is unshakable, firmly abiding in truthful speech like Mount Sumeru, by the causes and conditions of these karmic actions, they attain the mark of having feet as flat as the bottom of a tray.

If bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas use Dharma-like wealth to make offerings and provide for their parents, preceptors, teachers, and even animals, by the causes and conditions of these karmic actions, they attain the mark of having a thousand-spoked wheel on the soles of their feet.

If a bodhisattva-mahÄsattva does not kill or steal, and always gives rise to joy towards parents, teachers, and elders, through the causes and conditions of these karmic actions, they will attain three characteristics:
First, their fingers are slender and long; second, their heels are long; third, their body is square and straight.
These three characteristics have the same karmic cause.

If a bodhisattva-mahÄsattva cultivates the four means of conversion to gather in sentient beings, through the causes and conditions of these karmic actions, they will attain webbed fingers, like the king of white geese.

If a bodhisattva-mahÄsattva, when their parents, teachers, and elders are suffering from illness, personally washes and wipes them, and holds and massages them, through the causes and conditions of these karmic actions, they will attain soft hands and feet.ğŸ”½If a bodhisattva-mahÄsattva upholds the precepts, listens to the Dharma, and gives generously without weariness, through the causes and conditions of these karmic actions, they will attain ankles and knees that are full, and body hairs that point upward.

If a bodhisattva-mahÄsattva single-mindedly listens to the Dharma and expounds the correct teachings, through the causes and conditions of these karmic actions, they will attain the shanks of a deer king.

If a bodhisattva-mahÄsattva does not give rise to a harmful mind towards sentient beings, is content with food and drink, always delights in giving, and provides medicine for the sick, by the power of these karmic causes, their body is perfectly round like a nyagrodha tree.
Their hands reach down to the knees, and their head has a fleshy crown protrusion, with the mark of the invisible crown.

If a bodhisattva-mahÄsattva sees those who are frightened and protects them, and sees those who are naked and gives them clothes, by the power of these karmic causes, they attain the mark of the hidden male organ.

If a bodhisattva-mahÄsattva associates with the wise and avoids fools, is good at asking questions and answering, and sweeps the roads, by the power of these karmic causes, their skin is fine and soft, and their body hair curls to the right.
